question.text: The specific heats <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>C</mi><mi>P</mi></msub></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>C</mi><mi>V</mi></msub></math>, of a diatomic gas <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>A</mi></math> are <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>29</mn><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">J</mi><mo> </mo><msup><mi>mol</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>22</mn><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">J</mi><mo> </mo><msup><mi>mol</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></math> respectively. Another diatomic gas <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>B</mi></math>, has the corresponding values as <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>30</mn><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">J</mi><mo> </mo><msup><mi>mol</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>21</mn><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">J</mi><mo> </mo><msup><mi>mol</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></math> respectively. Which among the following is correct?

options.text: A has one vibrational degree of freedom and B has two vibrational degrees of freedom
A has one vibrational degree of freedom and B has zero vibrational degree of freedom
A and B both have one vibrational degree of freedom
A and B both have two vibrational degrees of freedom

solution.text:
If f is the degree of freedom of a gas molecule, then

CPCV=f+2fCPCVA=2922=fA+2fA⇒fA=6CPCVB=3021=fA+2fA⇒fB=5

So A has one vibrational degree of freedom and B has none
